An adapter designed for the racerstar 1103 motors to adapt 3" triblade propellers. Designed with gemfan 3035 triblades in mind but may work for others. Press the adapter into the prop hub from the top, which may require some force from a press or (lightly!) a hammer. the props will need to be trimmed to fit the XBL, nail clippers work great. I will probably make a jig but just inserting til they hit the bar at the front has been pretty consistent for me so far.

Once hub is installed onto the props, drill out shaft hole to 1.4 or 1.45mm using a carbide PCB drill, I use 1.45mm and they seem to fit snug. Prop is meant to sit directly down against the top surface of the motor bell, the cutout on the bottom is meant to accommodate the boss surrounding the motor shaft on top of the motor. This prevents any vertical play. May require some printer settings or scale tweaking to get these to fit appropriately, use at your own risk!

I haven't field tested these props yet but livingroom hover/punch test looked promising :)

Edit: .sldprt uploaded too if you need to modify.

comments.author: p3ck

description.text:
I decided to build a Proton Pack from the new Ghostbusters movie for Halloween and after searching Thingiverse I found crydrk's proton pack which they made before the movie was released from the limited number of promotional photos available in 2015. It was amazingly accurate but in doing so it was made up of a lot of parts and would take a long time to print and assemble. I then decided to simplify it and make it easier to print and assemble.

What has been done:
Blended multi part boxes into single prints.
Made objects solids instead of hollow. This means no inside perimeters so when using low infill it takes less material and less time.
Replaced large inner dome parts with smaller quick prints.
Added holders for el wire coil inside the center dome.
Added gun mounts for side of pack and gun based on comicon pictures of actual prop.
I also remodelled several other parts but it has been a few months since and I can't remember it all.
I also corrected a few small things I noticed now that there was more info about the packs available. eg. moved lower yellow striped bar mounts to outside of angle iron end plates.

I used an Arduino Pro Mini 5v 328
An old hipstreet mp3 player to add sound.
A portable rechargeable cell phone speaker.
A 5 metre red el wire kit from gearbest.com with 2aa battery pack included that I hacked to allow pwm control.
A couple of white 5050 l.e.d.s from a length of l.e.d. strip lighting for the number displays.
9v battery and connector for the Arduino.
Metal broom stick from the dollar store.
Small push button for trigger.
1/2" copper pipe and assorted elbows and solder.
Misc. wire, tubing, zip ties, screws, bolts, wood, acrylic sheet, paint and aluminium tape.

When you multi click the button it turns the unit on/off. During the power on cycle the brightness of the el wire increases and the audio track of the start up sound plays. Once running the el wire pulses slowly. If you hold the button down the el wire strobes at a high rate. Unfortunately you can not see the strobing light in the video.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3wwBAudtkeg&feature=youtu.be&spfreload=10

I've included the Arduino sketch. Its a little hacky and the double click is a little finicky but worked and was easy to implement. The mp3 player would continuously loop and if paused would go into standby which you could not fix via software. To solve this I made a blank audio track 20 min long and once the start up sound played it would play the blank track. This meant if you triggered a start up again the Arduino would request the next/last track after the blank track which was actually the first track, the start up sound.

It is currently slightly smaller than the dimensions mentioned on the internet of the actual prop. I believe it is about 10% smaller. At this scale the gun barrel is made out of a thin metal broom stick measuring about 19mm in diameter.

The original fit 57mm wide playing cards, not 63mm wide ones as suggested. It is also quite tall and has a generous base.

But it looks good and has a nice taper to help keep the cards in. So I grabbed it, embiggened it by a few percent, trimmed the base and the top so that it holds my Exploding Kittens cards AND fits inside the original box. print_settings.Notes:: 5 shells, 5 bottom layers, 5 top layers (to prevent leaks and increase shell strength), 750 grams of ABS filament, and lots of patience.

description.text:
So you want to build a snowman, but you live in Florida.

Why not build some wax ones, that you can burn all night long?

The .stl mold is for casting a 6" tall ~1.2lb (~500g) snowman candle. If you'd like another size or different proportions, you can try the Customizer or .scad file. The customizer shows the snowman "positive" for reference, you could print that directly if you wanted a plastic snowman instead of a candle.

I'm crediting the Moai head candle molds as partial inspiration for this venture - I made a double sized (4" tall) Moai mold and getting soy wax out of the plastic was.... challenging.

At present, this is a work in progress... The intent is to make an "adorable" fully decorated snowman with coal eyes, carrot nose, etc. Rather than hold back to the last day of the remix challenge, I'm letting the mold out now before I figure out how the decorations will all work.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.14mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

5 shells, 5 bottom layers, 5 top layers (to prevent leaks and increase shell strength), 750 grams of ABS filament, and lots of patience.

Mold release

You can polish the mold with acetone vapor for a smoother surface, but it may lead to bigger seam lines. The wax will release even with some texture on the mold surface if you pour warm (or cold) enough water in the water jacket (4 openings on the bottom.) You can pour in boiling water, the ABS can take it, just be prepared to remove the molds quickly before the wax melts too much. Obviously (due to expansion) avoid freezing water to solid ice in the water jackets. You might want to experiment with various temperatures of wax and water to get your favorite surface texture on release.

And remember: wax is recyclable. If you don't like the way one candle comes out, you can melt it down and try again.

Bolt holes

For my printer, a 7mm design diameter bolt hole prints out as a pretty snug fit on 1/4" (6.35mm theoretical) bolts. The ends of the holes can be a little too small, especially if the print comes out less than perfect, so I cleaned out the holes using a 1/4" drill bit.

Alternatively, you could size the holes to 7.4mm or larger, but the extra slop would mean that it will be easier for the mold parts to misalign, making the seam lines bigger.

Water Jacket in a 4 part mold

The Moai mold seemed to have a couple of things making it difficult to work with (in 4" size).

First, the wax stuck to the mold too aggressively so it would crack down the middle. The water jacket in this design allows getting warm, hot or even ice cold water close to the wax-mold interface surface to soften or shrink it for easier release. In practice, the hot water jacket works, but what works even better for soy wax is putting the mold in the freezer, and paraffin wax seems to release well with ice water in the water jackets.

Second, the Moai mold is deep, making it hard to get leverage on the part to help release - that's what the 4 part mold does... extra seam lines, but half the surface area per mold block and no steep sides. This, combined with 4 hours in the freezer, is enough for an easy release of soy wax in the snowman mold. The 2 part Moai mold still doesn't work in the freezer.

I also had some concerns from the Moai experience about the wick staying centered, so I added a wick holder holder to this mold.

The "feet" on the mold ends are thought to help the finished part sit flat even when things like the wick holding toothpick and extra wax are built up on top.

The chamfered edges prevent the corner buildup artifacts from holding the mold blocks apart, and also give a good place to start prying the blocks apart. Unfortunately, they also make it easier to pour "jacket water" between the blocks - for this design: pour carefully. In the future, adding "jacket water roof and channeling" to the block ends might be a good design refinement.

The wick holder holder has a slight reverse draft, but that should help the final candle sit flat (by providing a uniform height rim around the outside of the bottom.)

In OpenSCAD, under Edit-Preferences-Advanced, I increased both of my cache sizes to: 1073741824 (1GB), this seems to help render times a bit, though my Broadwell i5 still takes more than 4 hours to render each .stl file, and Windows 10 task manager reports upwards of 8GB memory in use during the render.

Candlemaking There are a myriad of candlemaking guides on the internet, see the references section for a few links. In this project, you are using a plastic mold to form your candle into a snowman shape. Additionally, the waterjacket in the mold enables pouring hot or cold water into the mold to help the solidified wax release from a plastic surface, even a rough one. 3D printing makes the waterjacketed mold easier to manufacture than it might otherwise be. Higher grades can learn about latent heat of fusion and vaporization and thermal conductivity. All grades can learn about the boiling point of water (100C 212F), and melting point of wax (about 122F 50C.) See the related lessons section below.

Making a Snowman Candle Collect your hardware, candle making supplies, and 3D printed parts. There are many ways to make candles: colored, scented, beeswax, soywax, paraffin, hemp wicks, cotton wicks, etc. I chose to use straight white soy wax, no scent, and a hemp wick in a candlemaking wick holder. Feel free to follow other candlemaking guides, but keep in mind that this is a plastic mold. Common sense: most of these steps involve hot liquids, not super dangerous hot, but hot enough to hurt. Handle everything with care. Day 1 Pour "enough" soy wax flakes into a melting pot, be generous here - the whole point of getting a melting pot is so you can set it aside with the excess wax to remelt for the next pour. To me, the main drawback of having too much wax in the pot is that it takes longer to melt. I melt my wax by putting the melting pot in hot (almost boiling) water until the last of the solid wax has melted, then take it out and let it cool until it just starts to get cloudy and/or stick to the sides of the melting pot when swirled. Wax has low thermal conduction, melting the wax can take several minutes, then letting it cool to almost solid can take ~1/2 hour. Wick prep While the melted wax is cooling, I cut a length of wick that can go from the top of the bottom ball, to the bottom of the candle, then back up and out the pour hole wrapping around a toothpick (extra long...) Then, I cut a 2nd length of wick a little longer than the bottom two balls together. Fold the first wick to a length approximately the diameter of the bottom ball and tie the 2nd piece to the folded point - now, braid the triple section and twist the double section together and feed it through the wick holder. The object is to have a single wick in the top part, double in the middle and triple in the third, sort of following the increasing diameter of the candle. Then I assemble the wick holder into the mold, bolt the mold shut, and hold up the wick over the pour hole by wrapping it around a toothpick. Optionally, to promote slow and even wax cooling, you can pre-heat the mold in a warm oven - perhaps to 120F (50C) - don't overheat the mold if your mold faces are rough, the hot mold will let molten wax leak out where a room temperature mold will solidify the wax and prevent leaks. One note, though - barely melted wax pouring into a room temperature mold seems to "stick" to some surfaces pretty aggressively. When the wax is ready to pour, make sure all the mold blocks are assembled correctly, the joints are straight and flush and wingnuts are snug-tight on their bolts. Pour the mold full and heat up your leftover wax a bit so that it's ready to pour again at about 15 and 30 minutes after the initial pour... bear in mind that wax shrinkage times and volumes can vary a lot. The wax will shrink slightly as it cools, which can leave a void in the top of the candle, this tends to happen a lot around the wick... the solution is to pour in more wax to fill the void until the shrinking stops. There is a lot of waiting time while the wax solidifies and shrinks (and top-up pours need to be done), this is a great time to talk about the related lessons from the References section below. Now, let the candle cool in the mold. I have been leaving mine at room temperature for at least 4 hours, although I seem to get the best quality candles from soy wax by placing the mold in the freezer for 4+ hours after the initial cooling/solidification of the wax. Day 2 If you left your mold in the freezer for 4 or more hours, there's a good chance the mold will release with no effort. If, for any reason, the mold seems stuck - use the water jackets to help with the release process. Up until now, the "water jackets" should have been air filled, with their filler holes pointed down. Now that the candle is solid, you can remove the wingnuts and bolts, turn the mold over and fill the water jackets with warm to hot water. Soy wax melts around 125F (52C) so boiling hot water isn't necessary, but it will have to be hotter than 125F in order to transfer enough heat through the plastic to soften the wax. Give the top layer of wax enough time to release its grip on the mold surfaces, then gently peel them away one by one starting at the wick-end and try not to pour the jacket water all over the place. It is possible that the wax will release from the mold without hot water in the jackets, it is also rather easy to crack the wax down the middle by attempting to pull apart stubborn mold pieces. If it's stuck, use the hot water jacket - don't muscle it. There should be dimples indicating where the carrot and coals go, you can dip them in hot water to make it easier to then insert/melt their anchor ends into the candle. Repeat daily until you have more snowman candles than you can stand. Braided wick in the holder Triple wick, before braiding Snowman recycling in progress in the double boiler Candles out of the mold, before decoration.

Hardware 8pcs 1/4-20(or 28)x5.5" hex bolts
https://www.mcmaster.com/#91247a033 8pcs matching wingnuts
https://www.mcmaster.com/#92771a529 I like the fine thread for more secure tightening, but 1/4-20 also works well. If you want to use metric size bolts, you might edit the .scad file for a tighter fit on the bolt holes. 1/4x5.5" steel bolts are kinda easy to bend - if you're having trouble getting them through the holes, check to make sure they are straight. Candlemaking Supplies Wax, such as:
https://www.amazon.com/Candlemakers-Store-Natural-Soy-Wax/dp/B00WZ6N1QW (maybe not the best choice, melts too easily when burning) or: https://www.amazon.com/Country-Lane-Candle-Making-Wax/dp/B0011PK2KQ ~1.25lbs or 550g per candle. A melting pot:
https://www.amazon.com/Country-Lane-90016-pound-Pouring/dp/B007VFWW6C Wick ~18" or 45cm per candle :
https://www.amazon.com/EricX-Light-Beeswax-Organic-Standard/dp/B01I2YAV0Y Wick holders:
https://www.amazon.com/YING-LAN-200pcs-12-5mm-Sustainer/dp/B01HEV66X2 Toothpick, or similar stick to hold the wick up at the wax filling hole side. Feel free to vary these materials, there are a myriad of great choices available... If you want to economize, the wick can be cotton, and you can redesign the bottom of the mold to hold the wick directly instead of using a commercial wick holder (but, the wick holders are like $0.03 each, so....) You will need a heat source to melt the wax, an informal double boiler (melting pot in a larger pot with hot water) is an easy arrangement that protects the wax from overheating. Some people use thermometers to monitor process temperatures... if this is a science-art project, then, by all means use thermometers - there is definitely a different quality to the finished candle depending on the pour temperature and this can be the basis of a scientific experiment: "observe qualitative differences in finished candles when varying wax pour temperatures." On the other hand, I find that "melted" and "solidified" is usually scientific enough to get some kind of candle made. Optional: Scale to weigh raw wax and finished candle:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01DIY78LI Candy thermometer to monitor wax temperatures:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LET2BFC

• Candlemaking
  • heat of vaporization
  • heat of fusion
  • thermal conductivity
  • ratio and proportion
  • weight
  • measurement
  • density
2 days: 1 hour first day, 15 minutes second day - alternately, first day can be broken up between prep and pouring.

Printing the mold is the longest part First, print the mold and accessories as described above... this part is rather time consuming. While you are waiting for the 3D print to complete, you can order the other supplies you need from the Candlemaking Supplies section.

Candlemaking Guides https://www.candlescience.com/learning/soy-candle-making-kit-instructional-video https://candletech.com/candle-making/tutorials/ http://www.wikihow.com/Make-Homemade-Candles Related Physics/Chemistry lessons Water boils at 100C, water in a pot on the stove will heat up to 100C and then stay at that temperature due to the latent heat of vaporization. The 100C water in the double boiler is hot enough to melt wax, but not hot enough to vaporize or burn it. The flame in a candle burns at about 1400C https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candle#Temperature due to the relatively low thermal conductivity of wax http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/thermal-conductivity-d_429.html and its high heat of fusion https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enthalpy_of_fusion the candle forms a pool of melted wax that travels up the wick to be burned in the flame, but can still stand solid underneath the melt pool as in a pillar candle. Vaporized wax, combined with oxygen from room air in the presence of a flame is how a candle burns: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candle Related background material: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paraffin_wax https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soy_candle https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latent_heat#Table_of_specific_latent_heats If you have (and use) a scale to measure the wax before you melt it, and you blend two waxes like soy and paraffin, then you also have the opportunity to teach about ratios and proportions: https://www.khanacademy.org/math/pre-algebra/pre-algebra-ratios-rates For example, the paraffin wax is hard to break so you "take the chunks as they come" while the soy wax flakes are easy to measure out as desired. If you want a minimum of 500g of blended wax 75% paraffin 25% soy, how much paraffin do you need at a minimum? ( 500 x 0.75 = 375 grams, at least.) If you have 4 chunks of paraffn that weigh 117g, 153g, 242g, and 321g, what combination do you use? ( 153 + 242 = 395, closest to 375 without going under). Now, you have 395g of paraffin, how much soy do you add to get a 75/25 ratio? 395 x 25 / 75 = 131.7g of soy. For extra credit, after the pour, you have 41g of blended wax left over, can you make another candle with the same blend ratio using the 321g chunk of paraffin, or do you need to include the 117 chunk too? How much soy will you add to the mix? Lower grades can do simpler weights and measurement exercises: weigh the empty pour pot, weigh it with the wax to melt in it, weigh again when the wax has melted, weigh the empty mold, weigh the mold and pour pot after pouring the wax into the mold, weigh a finished candle. Make sure to record all measurements, then you can analyze the results later - was any wax spilled? Are there other unexpected differences in the measurements? (Note: if you pour paraffin at 140F, it will weigh about 10% less per unit volume than it does at 70F, the shrinkage you observe after the initial pour is the paraffin contracting as it cools- mostly when it transitions from liquid to solid, note that this is the opposite of water which expands when it freezes into ice.) Higher grades may be interested in a more complex explanation of what is going on when the wax cools: https://books.google.com/books?id=SeC-7cx8KKUC&pg=PA96&lpg=PA96&dq=paraffin+volume+vs+temperature

Cost

This is a relatively expensive 3D printing project. First, there's 750 grams of filament (and 4+ days of printing), I suppose you could skimp on the 5,5,5 layering, but when I've tried 3,3,3 I've had some leaks and bubbles. So ~$15 for the ABS.

Then, if you buy the bolts and wing-nuts from mcmaster.com, they are another $15 delivered - you might skimp out to about $7 if you go for standard hardware from the local store and use wrenches to tighten the nuts.

Then there's the wax, I spent ~$15 for 5 lbs, and a $12 melting pot, and $10 for wick, wick holders, toothpicks...

Per candle, you're looking at something less than $4 each for wax, wick, holder, and filament for the decorations.

Soy vs Paraffin Wax

First, let me say that not all waxes are the same - different suppliers' wax may have different behavior, and even the same labeled wax from some suppliers may vary per batch. Second, the soy wax I purchased was labeled in some places as "general purpose" and others people said that it was not suitable for pillar candles. You can purchase wax with additives pre-blended into it, or purchase additives separately and blend them yourself to affect your candle's color, scent and texture. So far, I'm going with the straight uncolored unscented waxes for my snowmen, and this has been my experience. There's a lot written on the internet about candle making and waxes, most of it similarly biased to the authors' limited experience. If anyone reading this knows of a good, unbiased guide that would be helpful to snowman candle makers, please give us a link in the comments.

My first candles were made with 100% soy wax flakes (supplier link above). The flakes are very easy to work with pre-melting, you can measure them on a scale and get just what you need to make a candle melting in your pot. When melted, the soy wax seems to have a higher viscosity and a smoother transition from liquid to solid. I found it easier to "judge" the soy wax viscosity without a thermometer prior to pouring and had no problems with the mold leaking due to hot runny wax seeping out through small cracks (except the one time I poured very hot wax into a heated mold). The soy wax also seems to cool a little faster and shrink a little less than the paraffin, requiring less "top up" pours over maybe a 30 to 45 minute period if you do the initial pour with cooler liquid soy wax. On the downside, the soy wax also doesn't harden as much as paraffin and the final product is soft and oily. I have had good burns of soy snowman candles, but if you don't attend the candle, it can start dripping and if you don't stop it, you'll have a big melt puddle, which, of course will harden and can be easily recycled into a new candle later... As mentioned above, the best release method I've found after about 6 soy candle pours is to put the mold in the freezer for 4+ hours after the top-up pours are done. I haven't observed any cracking or other problems with freezing the soy wax, though it may be making it release a little more oil than non-frozen pours. One feature of the soy wax candles I've made has been voids from shrinkage in the lower parts of the candle - I think using a thermometer to control the pour temperature would help with this, it seems worse with hotter pours.

I melted about a 300g mix of soy and paraffin to use up the leftover soy wax and poured it into my mold. Viscosity was much lower and I did have a problem with leakage. The mixed wax is much less oily and has a firmer surface texture. The small print text on the candle is much easier to read. It also demonstrated significant shrinkage. I put the mold in the freezer and did get a split in the bottom of the candle, but it released from the mold very easily, and the split is not a big deal. Even though I did a relatively hot pour, I didn't see any lower area voids like the 100% soy hot pours.

Pouring my first 100% paraffin snowman now. I got my paraffin wax from Amazon (link above) but later noticed the same brand wax for the same price at my local hobby store. This paraffin came in a 10lb block, and that's a little harder to handle than the flakes, you need to crack off pieces and they tend to be a little big, or crumbly small; in the end it just melts in the pot - but with less control of how much you're putting in. Before the wax pour, I put ice water in the water jacket, theory being that wax intrusion into the small cracks would be solidified by the cold mold plastic. Apparently, that part worked - no leaks. I'm not too worried about surface-temp shock since the ice water all pours out before the wax pours in, and there's not much thermal mass in the mold faces to go up against the thick mass of the candle body wax, just enough in the small cracks to stop leakage. The paraffin does seem to shrink a lot more than the soy, I was topping up every 5 minutes for over 40 minutes, then I went to bed and in the morning there was another big void, two more top ups seem to have filled it. An hour after the top-ups, I removed the bolts - the molds didn't release easily, so I tried filling the water jackets with ice water and waited for a minute, after that the mold blocks came off without damaging the candle surface.

In the photo, the partial snowman is the soy-paraffin blend. The translucent one is 100% paraffin, and the white on the right is 100% soy. You can easily see the voids in the soy candle, there is a smaller void in the paraffin, but it's much less objectionable in nature and harder to see (near the bottom-right of the middle ball...) I think, overall, a soy-paraffin blend may be the way to go for best color and texture.

Edit: at this point I have poured about 4 soy-paraffin blend (approx 25% soy) snowmen, they're mostly void-free and have great color and texture, not oily like pure soy wax. I have also been able to make the original Moai head mold work using the soy-paraffin blend (or straight paraffin), by putting it in the freezer to loosen the wax from the mold.

title: Robo 3D Dual Fans with IR sensor mount

description.text:
This is a Dual Fan setup for a Robo 3D with the Hexagon Hot End.

There are 4 fan enclosures included, the front, rear and a rear with 2 mini IR sensor mount, one adjustable mount and one fixed. All 4 have a slider option to modify air flow. I designed this to be used with the Noctua 40mm NF-A4x10 fans if you plan to use other fans you will need to modify the fan mount to allow screws in the top fan holes (STEP file included). For the Noctua there are two pegs at the top and holes for screws for the bottom of the fans, the pegs alone will hold the fan. I've included screens for the fans along with spacers for between the IR board and the mount and a template for aligning the sensor. Use two M2 X 6 machine screws and a nylon insert lock nut for each. I had a regular nut vibrate off prior to using them. These will work on a stock Robo 3D R1(+) without modification.

I printed with PLA using S3D and supports are required for the fan mounts, other parts need no supports.

The Guide.stl is a light guide, printed in clear, for the LED which now faces to the rear, this is experimental and I may change this in the future. New curved light guide added.

Note: I've updated the spacer to make it a little thicker and added a mini IR sensor version that has a fixed mount with captive nuts. The z offset using this version should be -1.99 to -2.1.

You can align using my collimator collimator: just put the laser in the sight mount, and rotate the mount in the vee-shaped holes of the collimator collimator, while shining it at something a couple of meters away. Then adjust the adjustment screws until the spot doesn't move much when rotating (up to you how precise you dial it in).

title: Tevo Black Widow control box side mount

description.text:
To finish this control box I needed:
2x 80mm fans
24x #6 x 1/2in Flat Phillips Wood screws
Zip ties (PSU is secured with a Zip tie to the base)
8x M4x10 + drop in nuts for AL extrusion (to mount the box to the printer)
one 3Pin IEC320 C14 Inlet with Fuse and Switch
a few smaller screws to mount the board, the display and the power plug

I had to pilot drill for every screw to avoid damaging the printed parts.

The knob for the smart controller will need some modification because it is to long, I inserted a short piece of plastic so the knob does not slide on the shaft as far.

The size of the PSU mount is based on the stock part. For a different PSU you will have to modify the base plate.

The bottom fan is pulling air into the box and the top fan blows the air out of the box so you create an air flow from the bottom upwards.

title: Aloha's MiltyKoss Stepper Duct (Fits Mini Kossel and similar size deltas)

description.text:
Mini Kossel and similar size delta printer stepper fan duct. Fits 120mm fan for silent effective airflow using my standard 120mm 3 screw mod bracket.

Shown with a variable resistance dial to adjust RPM installed in place of the auto adjusting thermistor it came with (which was set to who knows what temperature). I leave the electrical up to you with the warning, research what you want to do with your fan and proceed at your own risk. The fan wires can pass through the mod bracket and be plugged in without modification. Simply cutting the fan frame away except for the hub and using the preexisting wiring uncut is the easiest method, sourcing a fan with a speed adjuster pre installed providing the simplest control. Wires can come loose though, use caution to protect you and your delicate printer electronics from loose wire shorts.

MiltyKoss Unit 2

I don't have any calipers, so I can't be exact, but one leg is slightly longer than the others. This causes the spinner to wobble at high speeds. Is there anyway you can upload a version that corrects this before I reprint a new spinner?
comments.author: Viking0612

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback! I am glad you liked my design. I generated this using OpenSCAD, and the legs are using the same code, just rotated by 120 from each other about the Z-axis, so they should be identicle in shape and length. I have just reviewed the code and confirmed that all 3 legs should be the same. Perhaps you want to check the weight of the bearings?
comments.author: Viking0612

comments.text: I printed the single. It was definitely a length issue though. I'm using the same bearings in a new design right now. One bearing was less than 1mm off. I'll try to print another at some point and see what happens. I was using Cura 2.3.1 on an Anet A8. Everything else about the spinner was perfect, no distortion, just that one bearing being off.
comments.author: Polaris2002

comments.text: I am not sure why you had that problem. To be very sure, I rechecked the OpenSCAD code, took each of the legs and rotate them one at a time by 120 degrees about the center to see if they match with the adjacent legs, and it check out fine. Then I opened the STL file that I have uploaded in Microsoft 3D builder, duplicated the object, rotated it by 120 degrees, and then overlap the 2 objects. They lined up perfectly. Let me know if you still have problems when you reprint it.

print_settings.Notes:: No need for supports. I created some solid support grid inside the feet (see print photo) so weight of machine is divided equal.

description.text:
After using the Spring based anti-vibartion feet for a while I wasn't too pleased with the result. To my opinion using the springs the machine is rather instable and shakes all the time especially when the head makes short movements. I think that because of the springs this "shaking energy" stays in the machine rather than being transferred away from the machine.

For this reason I created my own feet that raises the machine 30 mm and has a larger support area for the machine. I've been using them for a short while and I think the machine is much more stable. At least, it doesn't dance around anymore like with the spring-based feet. Adding some padding even makes them quiet as well.

You need the same feet for all 4 corners.

description.text:
Update 03/22/17: Updated to 3.10 version. Some tweaks to clearances around transmission.

Update 03/16/17: Uploaded re-worked design. Clearance was made around the link mounts. Transmission mount was lowered into the skid to increase interior clearance. Because of that other cutouts were needed for the motor and some other parts of the transmission. Please still note that if you're using the stock links you'll need to dremel/sand/file out the link slots to fit. Slots are designed for Revo style ball ends which are narrower than Axial. I would like to learn Fusion360 and design this from scratch sometime. I've also heard that the upper link upper mount holes aren't quite right and if you want to use them you'll need to change the link length.

Update 02/16/17: Finally got around to trying to install. Seems to be some lower link clearance issues with the design as-is. I'll need to make a few cuts to help out. Not sure when I will be able to accomplish this. Will update it when I can.

My first public design, feedback appreciated.

This is for the Axial Wraith rock crawler. Has a flat belly to give you about 7mm more ground clearance. I've also included upper link riser option. The lower upper link mounting position should keep stock geometry, the upper upper link mounting position should give you a little bit of link rise and keep your pinion angle the same.

The link slots have been designed for Revo rod ends, which have thinner balls than the Axial rod ends. If you are running Axial rod ends you will likely need to file down the lower link slots a little. The uppers should still work due to a bit of flex.

I highly recommend running an M3 tap through all the holes before screwing to help prevent tearing.

Some issues I foresee with the design:
1) Overall strength.
2) Upper link mounts are the weak point.
3) Upper link mounts will probably interfere with spur gear cover on transmission.
4) Possible link vertical geometry change.
5) Maybe drive shaft clearance on the skid (especially for lifted vehicles).
6) The transmission is moved up by 1.2mm. Could cause issues with interiors. Also slightly increases center of gravity.
7) Incorrect measurement and something doesn't line up.

I have not tested this print. So far I have only been able to test print the last version to make sure it was printable. Came out pretty good, and I made some tweaks. I won't be able to get one installed on an actual vehicle for some time.

I would love feedback on this and if you had any clearance issues. If everything clears nicely I could add material to the upper link mounts. Also, if there are no issue I would like the tweak the transmission mounting point. Get the transmission and motor to sit down a little lower.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Strength is the goal. I'm pretty new to 3D printing, but I would recommend about 4 walls, and a very high infill. As I said in the description, if you're running axial rod ends you will need to file down the lower link slots.

Tap all screw holes

M3 tap, as deep as you can. Go slow so you don't melt the plastic.

Plastocyanin, also called blue copper protein, is a copper-containing protein involved in electron-transfer:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plastocyanin The model is of the reduced form of plastocyanin at low pH (3.8). The Cu(I) ion is trigonally co-ordinated by N(His37), S(Cys84) and S(Met92). The fourth Cu-ligand bond is broken. This form of the protein is redox-inactive. Model of Plastocyanin from Poplar based on the Protein Data Bank entry 6PCY:
http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=6pcy STL file created using VMD:
http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/ The protein backbone is represented in "cartoon" form. The copper-binding histidine, cysteine and methionine, and copper ion are shown.

description.text:
I wasn't able to fit a Taulman 3D nylon spool on the stock maker select and I didn't like that many designs needed spool adapters, so I went ahead and designed my own that fits all spools I have ever come across without any adapters. The top pole mount is a spline at the bottom so that all spools should stay roughly centered, regardless of size.

I have uploaded the .step files if anyone would like to modify the files. The originals were done in Solidworks. The dimensions of the bearing mating surfaces may have to be changed depending on the tolerances of your printer. They should fit very snug.

You will only need one 608 Skate bearing for the mount and a small piece of PTFE is optional on the filament guide. The Spools turn very easy but you do have to make sure that your bearings have enough friction so that your spool won't unwind.

V2 Does not use a bearing now. Full assembly is printable and will have enough friction to not unwind spools.

BOTTOM_PLATE_SWIVEL replaced the original filament guide with a swiveling ball to allow for greater range of motion.

This is my own modified version of the D-Bot printer. I have designed / modified a part or two myself, and some other parts are ones I found off of thingiverse. (If I forgot to or miscredited a model, let me know!)

This build comes in at around $750-$800. I wanted to spec this printer to be able to print exotic materials at high accuracy with little to no compromises and maximum reliability.

I have been filming my progress building this 3D Printer on my Youtube channel Power Playground! Check out the 3D Printer VLOG video playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLMjfntGK5aY5IezSYz-a1cjPudUg71Mld

Original Part Sources:
D-Bot Printer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065
D-Bot 3-Wheel Titan Carriage: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833149
D-Bot 3-Wheel Titan Carriage Backer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833172
3-Wheel H-Bar Left: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833099
3-Wheel H-Bar Right: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833260
D-Bot 3-Wheel H-Bar Backer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833072
3-wheeled Z guide: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1802733
Adjustable bed holders: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1716262
Double beefy corner: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1859281
Mini Smart LCD Case: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:320117
Ramps 1.4 Enclosure - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1352320
V-Slot Tubing Clip: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1232213
T-Nuts for cable organization / LCD mounts http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1064782
Dbot 8mm z rod system: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2241762

All credit for the original C-Bot design goes to cfeniak.
Thanks to those who contributed at http://www.openbuilds.com/threads/c-bot.726/

The changes made from the original D-Bot are as follows:
-Overhauled the carriage system to use 3 wheels per carriage instead of 4. (Easier to tension)
-Replaced the bowden extruder setup with a direct drive e3d Titan extruder setup.
-Beefed up the build platform carriage, added in adjustable bed holders, and implemented Anti Backlash nuts for the Z acme lead screws.
-Upgraded stepper motor drivers and added an LCD / SD card reader.
-Reduced the amount of special hardware needed.
-Some other things I am forgetting at this time. :P

Future Changes:
-Modify H-Bar and Extruder blacking plates to allow room for the aluminum shim / spacer.
-Modify H Bar belt pulley pathways to have the corner chamfered / filet to allow easier installation of GT2 belts
-Change LCD mount
-Make some minor changes to the marlin firmware for the e3d extruder / hotend and the DRV 8825 stepper drivers.

3D Printer VLOG Change Log

12/12/16 - Found a rear frame clip for the extruder wiring.
12/23/16 - Improved Z-Endstop Screw Holder and Added a bracket to attach the 40mm fan duct to the titan carriage backing plate.
1/26/17 - Updated the marlin firmware for accurate steps per mm, e3d v6 pid settings and bang-bang bed temp settings for older relays. (Among other changes)
3/7/18 - Updated firmware to be able to be compiled in later versions of the Arduino IDE, (as well as tweaked the Z steps per mm) Switched the 2 motor Z lead screw system to a 3 lead screw belt train system to be used with 60 tooth gt2 pulleys, replaced 2 vwheels with 3x 8mm linear rods. Updated all the endstops, bed PWM / Relay Mount and a few other models I have probably forgotten to list here. Also updated the BOM since I have swapped out a few parts and am using aluminum brackets to hold the frame together now.

description.text:
UPDATE: Someone recommended to add divots so the lid doesn't slide around so I added them and uploaded them. If you want divots, download and print the updated files.

Hello. I love the game Portal 2 and have already printed a large companion cube, but was saddened by the lack of companion cube coin banks. That's when I remembered that I am an intermediate designer and opened it into Tinkercad. The rest is history, and now there is a super awesome and beautiful coin bank to show for 20 minutes. If you print one of these, click "I made one" and submit pictures and I promise to add them to the thumbnails. I have yet to print one but hope to do it soon. I highly recommend using the settings below, but depending on your desired outcome or printer, you can easily adjust these settings.

  • 0.2mm layer height
  • Thick shells
  • 20-30% infill
  • PLA (195 C - 220 C)
  • No retraction
  • 70mm/s print speed
  • 8mm brim (or skirt) to prevent parts from moving especially on glass beds

title: Extruder Body with PINDA probe support brace for Original Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
I modified the original Extruder body to add some more substantial support to the PINDA probe mount. I noticed that the probe didn't seem to be as perfectly centered in the little circles during Mesh Bed Leveling and realized that it was at a slight angle, not nice and vertical. It was more of a leaning-tower-of-PINDA. . .
Turns out that my mounting tab portion of the original extruder body that came with the kit had started to curve upward and the probe was no longer nice and vertical.
So I thought that a brace would help the probe retain stability over time and exposure to heat.

Installation note: you can slide the probe (with the top nut) from back to front through the opening, but if you want the part cooling fan to be nicely tucked away like it was originally, you will have to either unplug the part cooling fan from the circuit board to undo the wire and run it through the opening, or cut and splice the fan wire.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is a Hot-end part so ABS is the best choice, I believe that PETG will also work but it will be more flexible so I do recommend ABS. PLA is not suitable for Hot-end parts.

If you want to route the fan wire just above the original wire holder then you could do that instead.

title: Enclosure - Raspberry Pi 3b with 4 channel relay board

description.text:
This is an enclosure for a Raspberry Pi model 3B and 4 channel relay board. It includes 4 standard US plug sockets, Off switch, and a standard computer cord socket. This was created to cleanup my setup. Currently using OctoPi to control my Monoprice Maker Select IIIP. I am using the relay board to turn on/off the printer as well as the lights through the octopi interface. Instructions included by JeffeB3 here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1428478

Since I do not often need access to the Pi, I decided to stack the relay board on top of it. This reduced the space requirements but you will need to remember to plug in your gpio pin jumpers before installing the relay board on top of it. Enclosure was designed to use parts I already had on hand for another project. The rocker switch is only rated for 10amps so be sure not to plug any high powered devices into the outlets. I am currently only using 2 of the 4 channels on the board.

Parts List:
1x Raspberry Pi Model 2 or 3B
1 x SainSmart 4-Channel Relay Module: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0057OC5O8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1
1 x Enclosure Bottom Stacked
1 x Enclosure Top Stacked w/Supports
2 x Board Spacer
1 x Board Spacer2
1 x DigiKey Q212-ND: http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/qualtek/703W-00-04/Q212-ND/245553
4 x DigiKey Q227-ND: http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/qualtek/738W-X2-03/Q227-ND/245568
1 x DigiKey RA11131100-ND: http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?keywords=RA11131100-ND
2 x 3mm x 25mm hex head cap screws
4 x 3mm x 8mm hex head cap screws
16 guage wire.

author: lynno6

description.text:
This is designed to attach a second, dummy handlebar to aerobars. Aerobars usually take up all the space on the main handlebars, leaving no room for lights, a Garmin mount, etc.

It bridges the gap between the skis like so: https://i.ytimg.com/vi/fzLn_ayGTPk/maxresdefault.jpg but is more secure.

I made this for use with a Profile Design T3 set of aerobars, to mate to a standard 31.8 mm dummy handlebar. I use the dummy handlebar that came with the Profile Design set. I haven't installed it yet, but I don't see why it wouldn't work. If it doesn't, I'll update this.

STL & SLDPRT are provided for your convenience. Printed successfully with Lulzbot Mini with 3.0 mm PLA, using Cura.

• 0.2" wide zipties.

If have a hard time understanding the purpose of this, see here:

http://cdn.bikepacking.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/lael-wilcox-trans-am-race-55.jpg Notice the accessory handlebar attached to the aerobars perpendicularly. It looks like she drilled holes in the dummy handlebar to prevent rotation, but I imagine it still swings.

Tracks for zipties are provided for ease of installation. You might have luck with adding inner tube shims to increase friction. With weightier objects like lights, they may rotate & eventually end up at the bottom once you run over enough bumps. I designed this around some fairly standard zipties, with about 0.20" width.
26 Jan 17: added a picture with what I had to do before. It kept rotating forward with a light mounted every time I hit a bump. Don't recommend.

comments.text: Depends on your build. Mostly the lower wheels will stop it, some people drag the z bars along the rials, so the lower wheels aren't really necessary. comments.text:
Allted, thank you for working on this. Ever since I saw Printerbot work on their prototype I changed my perspective on how I would create a full sheet CNC. I'm in no position to work on this now as I have the MPCNC parts nearly printed but I wanted to pass on an some ideas to the community.
1) Use aluminum levels at your local box store like this as the primary support across the sheet to improve accuracy and stiffness.
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Empire-72-in-Box-Level-E75-72/207024931
They are expensive and extrusion may be cheaper anyway but if I came across a level for free... I don't like this idea too much because of the effort to encapsulate the level with bearings. :/
2) I haven't seen it yet but perhaps someone has used JB Weld to bond conduit and a flat metal brace where the bearings don' touch. This idea relates to the MPCNC because there are openings I see available. Your center assembly bearings would need to be raised.

description.text:
I accomplished a few things with this remix of the "Modular Plastic Conveyor Belt". I decided to add it under a few other tags where it could also fit in.

I didn't order all of my metal parts in time so I decided to print them. This conveyor is completely plastic. The shaft, couplers, frame, collars and bushings are all printed plastic. I will include the metal pieces in a parts list because this would make it more durable.

The links are designed to print inverted from the original design and still don't require support structures. It was a pain but worth the effort. The new orientation is important because now detail can be printed on top of the links. You could add chevrons, side walls etc. In this case I decided on Lego nubs so other plastic could be attached.

Once I had the lego belt links I decided to build the frame with legos. I have always been annoyed the limitations of connecting legos. Sometimes they seem more like a puzzle than a building tool. I designed simple gender changers and used male/male blocks to make the design symmetric.

This is pretty much a first draft and a lot could improve. Please publish any improvements. Let me know if you have questions etc.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.18 (cura 19.12 fine abs)

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is printed in ABS and the links are joined by sections of the same 3mm abs.

Cleanup the links

It's important to clean off any stray bits of plastic from the link juncture so the belt is flexible. This will result in a smooth running conveyor belt.

All of the shaft pieces (shafts, bearings etc) and lego fittings had to be cleaned up before they fit well.

Designed in Free Sketchup

I do most of my design in Sketchup. It's free and easy to use. I will post the drawing this time around in case anyone wants to modify or improve the design.

The motor coupler will press fit over the shaft and the motor shaft (couples them together). The belt links are 3/4" so you just print however many to make the belt length required. i'm sorry if this is vague. Let me know if you still have questions and I will try to help out.

description.text:
This design was definitely inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1957808. I would like to thank Strabe3d for the original.

The inner diameters are drawn at 22.1mm. You may or may not have to sand or use a vice depending on the accuracy from your calibration. It is designed right handed and if you are left, just rotate the model on the X or Y axis before printing.

Five 608 skateboard bearings are needed to complete the model.

Printer:

Mini Kossel

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm - 0.2mm

Infill:

At least 30% or higher.

Notes:

I use Mattercontrol for slicing.

The higher infill on this is for structural stability within the bearing satellite holes. Due to the open nature of the satellites, play it safe.

Use at least 3 shells or 1mm perimeter settings.

I also use a raft at the moment, but have printed just fine without. The same goes for the supports. Your slicer may not even see the need to place supports. I hardly ever print spinners with them enabled, but this is designed with a pronounced fillet and I believe supports will only help quality. Some spinners are like that.

This is also true of the lower resolution preferences. Truly, you can get away with 0.3mm, but it's a small print anyway. The lower resolution feels better in the hand and you will have a sense of pride while holding it. Test your printer's capabilities every chance you get.

For absolute perfection, you may have to adjust your slicer's triggered retraction distance (perhaps 20mm down to 3-5mm) to help with stringing along the vertices within the finger slots. There are two speed settings in Mattercontrol that can significantly help with oozing. They are your "travel speed for non print moves" and your "retraction length on move" settings. These may have to go faster or slower depending on your results. Experimentation is the best teacher at this point.

If successful and use Mattercontrol yourself (probably repetier too, idk), just make a profile to store your spinner settings. Do this especially if you design and sell your models.

Whew, seems like a lot for a spinner. I might have an addiction...

Anything you may need to do...

-sand?
-use a vice?
-glue?
-acetone?
-file?
-bake the model? (I'm serious on this one, it's a thing.) (Although, I'm too lazy for that, it's still there. See last sentence.)
-pick at burrs with fingers?
-Netflix and chill?

All choices you should make and not me.

print_settings.Notes:: tripod_foot_whole

title: Bendy Phone Tripod and Stabilizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bendy Phone Tripod and Stabilizer

A bendy tripod for any size phone, with the option of making it a phone stabilizer.

The phone mount has two modes: Tripod and phone stabilizer.

You could further remix this so that the base and connector pieces are used to mount other devices, like small videocameras.

In the interest of universal printability, all parts are made to fit in a 100mm x 100mm x 100mm printer.

Check the What to Print and Post-Printing tabs for printing, assembly, and use instructions.

 

Tripod

The tripod is designed to be flexible enough to use in any environment, to perfectly position your phone or small camera (This should be easy to modify to fit a GoPro, for example).

The tripod is remixed from giufini's PCB Workstation with Articulated Arms. I used the arms as the tripod legs, and changed the LED holder ending to a fully closed bulb shape for the foot.

 

Stabilizer

The stabilizer uses gravity and a simple gimbal system to keep your camera from shaking too much when you hold it and move, giving steadier video.

The stabilizer is remixed from artobot's Crazy Simple Camera / Phone Stabilizer.

I modified it to fit with the base of the tripod, reversed the pins and holes to make it more comfortable to hold without the rings, and made new handles with pegs to hold them in. While the legs of the tripod provide some weight, they are pretty light so I suggest adding more ballast for better performance. The feet of the tripod come in two variations. They can either be printed in one piece (and for this use solid would help) or in two, which allows them to be filled with another, heavier material.

Video comparing footage with and without the stabilizer, using about 1/4 lb of weight underneath.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10%-20%

Notes:

You will need supports for the lips on the phone_mount_bottom and phone_base, though everything else should print fine.

If you go for the single-part feet (tripod_foot_whole) it is a good idea to print it at 100% infill to add weight to the bottom, as it will help with stabilization.

Assembly

Thoroughly remove any support material before starting

 

Phone Mount

You will need two fairly small rubber bands.

  1. Loop one rubber band through each hole in tripod_phonemount_top and around itself, so that it is secure.
  2. Slide tripod_phonemount_top onto tripod_phonemount_bottom and pull the rubber band around the pegs. Once a phone is in, they should hold it tightly.
  3. Glue tripod_connector into the recess on the bottom of tripod_phonemount_bottom. I used superglue, and it holds fine.

Tripod

  1. Put the three tripod_leg_keys into their holes in tripod_base or stabilizer_base (stabilizer_base is the same as tripod_base but has holes for the gimbal system). You may need to sand, as the tolerances are pretty tight. I suggest gluing these in place anyway.
  2. Snap the tripod_leg_joints on, and end each leg with a tripod_foot. Do not glue these.
  3. Slide the assembled phone mount into the base.

Stabilizer

  1. Slide stablizer_inner_ring over stabilizer_base so that it clicks into place.
  2. Do the same with stabilizer_outer_ring.
  3. Connect the stabilizer_handles to stabilizer_outer_ring using the stabilizer_handle_pegs. I suggest not gluing these, so that you can take it apart for storage. However, it would add strength.
  4. (Optional) Add the stabilizer_extenders to the legs.

 

Use

The stabilizer should be taken off when not in use, as it gets in the way of the tripod. When putting it on, it is easiest to go from the top by sliding out the phone holder assembly.

Add the stabilizer_extenders to make the legs longer and more efficient.

Another way to add weight to the bottom of the tripod is to wrap the legs around something fairly heavy.

Tripod

  • 1x tripod_base (if you do not want to use the stabilizer) OR stabilizer_base (necessary for the stabilizer)
  • 1x tripod_connector
  • 1x tripod_phonemount_bottom Print this part laying down, as it will be much stronger and smoother.
  • 1x tripod_phonemount_top
  • 3x tripod_leg_key
  • 3x tripod_foot_top and 3x tripod_foot_bottom OR 3x tripod_foot_whole
    The split one is for people who want to use a different material or color for the bottom of the foot, such as a more rubbery filament for grip. Also good for filling up with a heavier material to act as a weight for the stabilizer.
  • Roughly 18-30x tripod_leg_joint, in multiples of 3. Printing more simply means longer legs.

Stabilizer

  • All of the above (Need to have printed stabilizer_base)
  • 1x stabilizer_inner_ring
  • 1x stabilizer_outer_ring
  • 2x stabilizer_handle
  • 2x stabilizer_handle_peg
  • (Optional) 3x stabilizer_extender

print_settings.Notes:: Easy part to print, but fit is important, so watch for over/under extrusion.

description.text: My Printrbot hotend's life came to an end from approximately three years of constant use, and the only hotend I had extra at hand was a Hexagon hotend, and I need a way to attach it to my printrbot. The problem is is that the hexagon hotend is considerably shorter than the original printrbot one, and due to my printers setup, a shorter hotend simply would not work. This is where I decided to come up with a way to adapt the hotend I had to fit, and this part was born. This is a hotend adapter to allow for my hexagon hotend to fit on my printrbot. The PTFE adapter allows the user to run a PTFE tube from the extruder to the hotend directly, allowing for a more direct filament path.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Go V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Easy part to print, but fit is important, so watch for over/under extrusion.

1x Hexagon Hotend
1x Hexagon Hotend Adapter
1x Bowden M6 Push Fitting
1x Some Bowden tube

• Blue Loctite
  • Super Glue
  • X-acto knife or anything to cleanly cut a PTFE tube
  • Wrench for fitting

Take push fitting and break off the blue/black plastic part. This is the part that releases the bowden tube, so don't expect to be able to remove the tube once installed. Add some blue loctite (blue so it can be removed in the future if needed) to the fittings threads and thread the fitting onto the hotend, making sure that the fitting is tight. Next, take the fitting and add some super glue to the outside (Optional: you may want to rough up the outside of the fitting to allow for a better adhesion surface for the glue to stick to), and tightly press the fitting into the printed part supplied here. If it is a tight fit, you can unscrew the fitting and press in the fitting with a vice, or other tool, but make sure the fitting can screw in far enough to ensure a tight seal against the hotend (make sure to add loctite again). Lastly, the PTFE tube can be inserted, and cut flush with the end of the adapter. (You can also leave some length out of the end to run all the way to the drive gears, but remember, this cannot be removed.)

description.text:
PostModern Deconstructed Snowflake

A pretty snowflake, deconstructed!

The flake is actually 3D, not just an extruded outline, and as been saved in three sizes, and deconstructed into sub-flakes to sprinkle around your tree. The design is in 6 sectors, that can be edited in and out with the scad file. The mid sized flake makes a nice item to post inside a card to someone.

This snowflake is designed to print with 0.25mm layers, and a 0.5mm extrusion width (0.4mm nozzle) the scad file can be edited to match other setups. This avoids slicer gaps and keeps the layer count even between the different heights. Sharp corners and narrow angle holes have been avoided, and the thickness steps are 1.5, 2.5 and 3 mm so each has plenty of layers for strength.

Enjoy!

PS Okay, okay - my white is a bit thready with my bowden setup, but it is just the right colour :) I'll clean them up, and those with better setup printers will get cleaner results.

description.text: This is a Lego 1x1 brick.
It is a weird shape and each part between the holes are .1 in and the full size is 3x3in

This filament spool holder should work with any Taz printer. There are other similar spool holders, but I made mine with a few ideals.

  • Minimalistic design to avoid wasting material and taking up space
  • Simple to install without needing excessive hardware or special parts
  • Support dual extruder systems by having a two spool capacity
  • Easy to swap spools without dismantling any parts

This is easy to print without any supports. I used 20% infill. Holes are provided so it can be secured to the rails with zip ties. Once this is done, it is very secure. The spool support I'm using is 1/2 inch PVC water pipe. The outside diameter for it is about 0.85 inches or 21.5mm. Just cut to length as necessary.

Taz 4 Bulldog Extruder holder usiing a E3d V6 1.75mm hotend. Its my first attempt. I modified the original holder from Lutz. Will see how it works...

(Update 12/11/2016) Modified the design to version 1.2. Expanded the base and made some adjustments to the hot end plate area, it was a bit to tight. Also added heatset holes (4mm) to mount a fan for the hotend. There are two versions one with a fan shroud and one without. Still testing...

(Update 12/12/2016) Printed the one with the fan shroud as I had one of these fan types laying around. The fan shroud didn't print well as my support settings were screwed up, I usually don't use support. Also the bottom hole for the fan was off... I'll blame that on Sketchup... should have used fusion.

Having said that after a very little bit of cleanup it went together okay, and this should be good enough for testing. See the photo's. I need to open up the horizontal opening for the mount just a tad. Now to test it. I'll wire it all up as soon as my connectors arrive from Digikey. Hopefully it all works as I have been needing a 1.75mm hotend to eat up all the 1.75mm filament I have...

I plan on moving the fan back a bit and printing a separate detachable fan shroud

I removed and depreciated version 1.1 as it was not going to work.

(Update 12/12/2016)

Hashed together a harness and got it working today, see video here: https://youtu.be/p1RlwsWjp7o

Printed a 5mm calibration cube after doing a quick extruder cal. It came out okay, still need to fine tune it, but I'm about to upgrade this printer to a TAZ 6, have all the parts, now I have a working 1.75mm toolhead to go with my 3mm toolhead...

A couple of things you need to know. The X home position is now about 15mm off the edge of the bed. You will have to re calibrate the esteps, you can start with 500 as a ballpark.

author: Hustle_Designs

description.text:
First, what is a Pythagorean Cup? In laymen's terms, it's a cup behaves normally until it's filled past a certain level, at which point it drains the entire contents out the bottom through a siphon tube.

For a more detailed explanation on its history and how it works, look at the wikipedia article on it, that provides a good summary.

Second, a Pythagorean Cup normally has a giveaway column in the middle of the cup, which contains the siphon tube. That's where this model is different.

I've created a cup that does the exact same thing, except the siphon tube is contained in the wall of the cup. I felt that the column rising through the center of the original design was somewhat distracting, and that the cup would be much cooler without the column.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.21875

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you choose to scale this model up or down in your slicer, I advise against scaling down, or the siphon tube might become too small to function. As it is, the total height of the cup is 4.45 inches.

Update 12/29/16:
The model is on the border of being too small. For better results, scale the model up by 1.2x on the horizontal axes (X & Y). Or if you wish, on the Z axis as well. I'm working with a small-volume printer, so I personally can't scale the Z axis any larger.

comments.text: The point of the column is so it doesn't siphon or leak when someone takes a sip from a properly filled cup. Perhaps devise a way to keep them from drinking out of the wrong side?

Version 1 of a flight sim yoke. I am busy slicing and enhancing.

I have now added sections for the handles. Each handle side has an elbow and a head unit. Combine a right and left complete set to create a full handle. Then repeat for another handle. This will give you a partial yoke minus the boss (I will upload once I have test printed it).

The spaces in the heads are there to allow for customization of button panels that can be added. I will add some once I have been through that process.

I have added a v2 of the back of the boss unit. This now contains a hole to help with the routing of cables for the button panels on the handle heads. The first version (which I will leave here) made it way too hard to route cables around once all glued together.

It was printed upside down, with support for curvature. All parts were just glued together with superglue, and finished with a wash of acetone.

author: Modolf

description.text:
This is a library function that fits between linear_extrude() and rotate_extrude(). It takes a 2D object and extrudes it in a spiral. Unlike linear_extrude, the 2D object is perpendicular to the path of the extrusion.

This would have been much easier if OpenSCAD would allow me to access the points that make up the 2D objects the function is operating on.

Comment out the example before using this as a library. I left it uncommented so that Thingiverse would show a picture of the example.

Update: I found a bug where when the radius was less than 20, it would fail to generate anything. I found that the calculation inside the asin() function was resulting in 1+1e-14 which is not allowed for the asin() function, so it was returning nan. I have limited the result to a range of -1 to 1 to fix the problem.

Update 2: Adjusted the size of the spiral segments so the segments slightly overlap (eliminates gaps in spiral). Added render() to segment because OpenSCAD was complaining of too many objects, and getting slow. Changed atan() to atan2() to avoid potential divide by zero. Added version number to file. (this version is 1.2).

author: isaacho

title: Belt redesign for FT5 using  F625ZZ bearings

description.text:
Who has had issues already with the GT2 pulleys on Y and X? I did! I replaced these small bearings already several times and decided to finish that by using large ones.
In this design I used F625ZZ (16mm x 5mm with flange). I mounted them both on a 25mm long 5mm bolt with flanges to the outside (see pictures).
What did I need :
2 pulleys for the Y-axis.
New supports for the Y-steppers (I wanted to get rid of the the whole melamine piece under both Y-belt channels - no worries about the length of the rods : see picture)
Supports for the cablechain on the right side.

Whats special about the pulleys : while still warm, I screw the bolt in and create as such a thread that holds quite good
The LEFT X-pulley : 2 pieces now. I made a separate support for the bearing to allow nicer and more accurate printing
One could also mount the Y-pulley supports upside down and leave the melamine base.

I replaced the bed support by an aluminium one made of standard 2mm thick profiles.

Modified cablechain support items : 50mm instead of 60mm
Everything mounted and tested ...

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2045169 for a revised version. In the revision belt tension adjustment is done with the pulley instead of the stepper

Printer:

FT5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,4mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

I printed these in PET. support is only needed for the left X-support.
I used a 0,6mm nozzle
See S3D screenshots for settings
I usually drill the holes to the correct size. That's the reason why I use 5 shells. This gives also extra strength for the support of the bolt when fastening.

description.text:
The lantern is 8,8 cm tall, and 6,4 cm wide. Candles up to 4 cm diametre fit in it. The lantern is out of 4mm plywood. To get it wind proofed, you need 3mm acrylic glass. But if it only has to stand indoor, you don`t need it.
The wooden ring should only be used for glueing it together and not to glue it on the lantern. It can be put on the lantern while the glue is cureing. So the lantern will be symmetric.

title: Motor mount + Landing legs for 10mm square tube

description.text:
UPDATE: Added a snap op landing leg. Secures with a zip tie. Made for easy replacement  after a crash.  
This remake is made for 10mm square tubes. It contains a motor mount and landing legs as seen on the pictures.   
The holes for the motor are 16mm and 19mm apart. It's perfect for my HP2212-1000kv motors.   
The actual clearance is 10,25mm. It is still a thight fit so you might need to use some sandpaper to make it fit. Make sure the landing legs fit snug enough so they will stay in place because there are no holes for bolts.  
There is a hole on the end of the motor mount so you can run the motor wires through the tube for a nice and tidy copter!
I used 40% infill for both and it seems though enough so far!

comments.text: Printed in ABS. I have no problems with any warping, they work like they should. Sorry for the late response.
comments.author: Rop922

comments.text: I really like the mount for the HP2212 motors.  Did you print it in PLA or ABS, and did you have any problems with it warping due to high temperature of the motor case?
